              presented by
              Home / Decorating

              10 DIY Fall Wreaths That Are Way Better Than a Welcome Mat

              Your neighbors will be oh-so-jealous when they see one of these hanging on your front door.

              By Samantha Zabell
              March 22, 2015
              • 2k
              • 782
              • 936
              • Save
              1

              Autumn Wreath

              Photo by Lacquer and Linen

              Raid your craft closet and the store for fun, seasonal add-ons that will make your door the envy of the neighborhood. If you can’t find every item that this blogger uses in her wreath, customize it based on your taste, and your supplies. The feathers, though, are easy to make—they’re just paper.

              Get the tutorial at Lacquer and Linen.

              2

              Monogram Wreath

              Make your door décor personal this season by painting a wooden letter to attach to your wreath. This crafter went with a fun, polka-dot pattern, and the large letter balances out the flowers and ribbon on the opposite side of the wreath. Get the kids involved with this one—ask them what they want the family colors or pattern to be, then reflect that in the monogram!

              Get the tutorial at Tidy Mom.

              3

              Hydrangea Wreath

              This flowery wreath is deceptively simple—the base itself is just a cardboard floral craft ring. This blogger’s color scheme is particularly fall-friendly, and fake flowers mean that you don’t have to worry about your festive door decoration shriveling up and drying out.

              Get the tutorial at A Night Owl.

              4

              Ruffled Wreath

              Photo by Positively Splendid

              This picture-perfect wreath is so pretty and feminine—we love the use of buttons and brooches as rosette centers. One caveat: You need a sewing machine for the ruffle effect. If you don’t have one, you can simply wrap the fabric around the wreath base—the color scheme and embellishments are enough to make this wreath look welcoming.

              Get the tutorial at Positively Splendid.

              5

              Ombré Rosette Wreath

              Photo by Flamingo Toes

              It seems like rosette embellishments are a must-have for fall wreaths, and this blogger has a step-by-step guide to making them. Pro tip: She advises ripping the fabric into strips, because the frayed edges add to a more rustic look. For the base, you need a grapevine wreath, which you can purchase at your local craft store (here’s one from Michaels).

              Get the tutorial at Flamingo Toes.

              6

              Burlap Wreath

              The best part about this incredibly simple wreath is that the floral embellishments can be changed according to the season—you can attach snowflakes in the winter, or brighter flowers in the spring. This crafter repurposed old hair clips to make the flowers easy to detach.

              Get the tutorial at Craftaholics Anonymous.

              7

              Cornhusk Bow Wreath

              Everyone talks about how to turn pumpkins and gourds into seasonal décor, but what about cornhusks? The deep purple husk is a nice finishing touch to a simple fabric wreath—and would be a pretty, seasonal embellishment on a wreath of any style. You can find cornhusks at craft stores, grocery stores, or even farmers markets.

              Get the tutorial at The Cards We Drew.

              8

              Fall Straw Wreath

              Photo by Echoes of Laughter

              This straw wreath (you can see it poking through the ribbon!) reminds us of our favorite parts of fall: pumpkin picking and hayrides. The off-center cluster of flowers is eye-catching without being too hectic or distracting, which is perfect for a glass window.

              Get the tutorial at Echoes of Laughter.

              9

              Paper Wreath

              Don’t let the look of this project stress you out—the blogger used a scalloped paper punch as a shortcut, although you do have to glue them on individually. The rest of the materials are ones you probably have at home—like paper, a pencil, and a glue gun. Seriously, it’s that simple!

              Get the tutorial at Make Life Lovely.

              10

              Washi Tape Wreath

              Photo by Tater Tots and Jello

              Although this bright and colorful wreath is billed for Halloween, you can use different colors or patterns of tape around the lids to make it appropriate all season long. Start stocking up on old jars so that you don’t have to buy them at the store. Neighbors or friends might have old ones lying around!

              Get the tutorial at Tater Tots and Jello.

              Follow Real Simple

							<div class="kicker dib"><a itemprop="articleSection" href="#">Home</a>  <span class="divider">/</span> <a itemprop="articleSection" href="#">Decorating</a>  </div>
							<h1 class="lead-headline" itemprop="headline">10 DIY Fall Wreaths That Are Way Better Than a Welcome Mat</h1>
							<h2 class="lead-subtitle" itemprop="alternativeHeadline">Your neighbors will be oh-so-jealous when they see one of these hanging on your front door.</h2>
							<div class="article-meta">

									<div class="b-inner cf">
								    <div class="b-head">
								      <span class="number--large listicle-number">1</span>
								      <h2 class="b-title">Autumn Wreath</h2>
								    </div> <!-- /.b-head -->
								      <div class="b-thumb">
        <div class="img-wrap  has-credit ">
          <div class="img-inner">
              <div class="has-social">


      <img class="lazy" data-original="http://cdn-image.realsimple.com/sites/default/files/styles/rs_photo_gallery/public/owl-wreath.jpg" itemprop="image" alt="Lacquer and Linen" />
      <noscript><img src="http://cdn-image.realsimple.com/sites/default/files/styles/rs_photo_gallery/public/owl-wreath.jpg" alt="Lacquer and Linen"></noscript>




              <div class="img-overlay o-social"><div class="social-share">
  <ul class="ss-list">
    <li class="ss-item">
      <a class="ss-link" href="#">
        
        <span class="no-bg icon rounded icon-pinterest icon--big"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="146 290 500 500" enable-background="new 146 290 500 500">

              </div> <!-- /.has-social -->
          </div> <!-- /.img-inner -->

              <span class="credit">Photo by Lacquer and Linen</span>

        </div> <!-- /.img-wrap -->
								      </div> <!-- /.b-thumb -->
								    <div class="b-text">
								      <div class="dek text">
								        <p>Raid your craft closet and the store for fun, seasonal add-ons that will make your door the envy of the neighborhood. If you can’t find every item that this blogger uses in her wreath, customize it based on your taste, and your supplies. The feathers, though, are easy to make—they’re just paper.</p>
								          <p>Get the tutorial at <a href="">Lacquer and Linen</a>.</p>
								      </div> <!-- /.dek -->
										</div> <!-- /.b-text -->
									</div> <!-- /.b-inner -->
								</div> <!-- /.block-listicle-item -->

									<div class="b-inner cf">
								    <div class="b-head">
								      <span class="number--large listicle-number">2</span>
								      <h2 class="b-title">Monogram Wreath</h2>
								    </div> <!-- /.b-head -->
								      <div class="b-thumb">
        <div class="img-wrap ">
          <div class="img-inner">
              <div class="has-social">


      <img class="lazy" data-original="http://cdn-image.realsimple.com/sites/default/files/styles/rs_photo_gallery/public/monogram-wreath.jpg" itemprop="image" alt="Tidy Mom" />
      <noscript><img src="http://cdn-image.realsimple.com/sites/default/files/styles/rs_photo_gallery/public/monogram-wreath.jpg" alt="Tidy Mom"></noscript>

              </div> <!-- /.has-social -->
          </div> <!-- /.img-inner -->


        </div> <!-- /.img-wrap -->
								      </div> <!-- /.b-thumb -->
								    <div class="b-text">
								      <div class="dek text">
								        <p>Make your door décor personal this season by painting a wooden letter to attach to your wreath. This crafter went with a fun, polka-dot pattern, and the large letter balances out the flowers and ribbon on the opposite side of the wreath. Get the kids involved with this one—ask them what they want the family colors or pattern to be, then reflect that in the monogram!</p>
								          <p>Get the tutorial at <a href="">Tidy Mom</a>.</p>
								      </div> <!-- /.dek -->

								    <div class="b-head">
								      <span class="number--large listicle-number">3</span>
								      <h2 class="b-title">Hydrangea Wreath</h2>

								    <div class="b-text">
								      <div class="dek text">
								        <p>This flowery wreath is deceptively simple—the base itself is just a cardboard floral craft ring. This blogger’s color scheme is particularly fall-friendly, and fake flowers mean that you don’t have to worry about your festive door decoration shriveling up and drying out.</p>
								          <p>Get the tutorial at <a href="">A Night Owl</a>.</p>

        </div> <!-- /.img-wrap -->
								      </div> <!-- /.b-thumb -->
								    <div class="b-text">
								      <div class="dek text">
								        <p>This picture-perfect wreath is so pretty and feminine—we love the use of buttons and brooches as rosette centers. One caveat: You need a sewing machine for the ruffle effect. If you don’t have one, you can simply wrap the fabric around the wreath base—the color scheme and embellishments are enough to make this wreath look welcoming.</p>
								          <p>Get the tutorial at <a href="">Positively Splendid</a>.</p>
								      </div> <!-- /.dek -->
										</div> <!-- /.b-text -->
									</div> <!-- /.b-inner -->

								      </div> <!-- /.b-thumb -->
								    <div class="b-text">
								      <div class="dek text">
								        <p>It seems like rosette embellishments are a must-have for fall wreaths, and this blogger has a step-by-step guide to making them. Pro tip: She advises ripping the fabric into strips, because the frayed edges add to a more rustic look. For the base, you need a grapevine wreath, which you can purchase at your local craft store (here’s one from <a href="">Michaels</a>).</p>
								          <p>Get the tutorial at <a href="">Flamingo Toes</a>.</p>
								      </div> <!-- /.dek -->
										</div> <!-- /.b-text -->
									</div> <!-- /.b-inner -->

								    <div class="b-head">
								      <span class="number--large listicle-number">6</span>
								      <h2 class="b-title">Burlap Wreath</h2>
								    </div> <!-- /.b-head -->

        <div class="img-wrap ">
          <div class="img-inner">
              <div class="has-social">

              </div> <!-- /.has-social -->
          </div> <!-- /.img-inner -->


        </div> <!-- /.img-wrap -->
								      </div> <!-- /.b-thumb -->
								    <div class="b-text">
								      <div class="dek text">
								        <p>The best part about this incredibly simple wreath is that the floral embellishments can be changed according to the season—you can attach snowflakes in the winter, or brighter flowers in the spring. This crafter repurposed old hair clips to make the flowers easy to detach.
								          <p>Get the tutorial at <a href="">Craftaholics Anonymous</a>.</p></p>
								      </div> <!-- /.dek -->

								      <h2 class="b-title">Cornhusk Bow Wreath</h2>

              <div class="has-social">

      <noscript><img src="http://cdn-image.realsimple.com/sites/default/files/styles/rs_photo_gallery/public/corn-husk-bow-wreath.jpg?itok=iPMY0B-W" alt="The Cards We Drew"></noscript>




              <div class="img-overlay o-social"><div class="social-share">
  <ul class="ss-list">
    <li class="ss-item">
      <a class="ss-link" href="#">
        
        <span class="no-bg icon rounded icon-pinterest icon--big"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="146 290 500 500" enable-background="new 146 290 500 500">
  <title>Pinterest</title>
  <path fill="#fff" d="M224.6 475.6c0 45.1 16.6 85.2 52.1 100.3 5.8 2.5 11.1.1 12.7-6.6 1.1-4.6 4-16.3 5.2-21.1 1.8-6.6 1-8.9-3.7-14.6-10.2-12.4-16.8-28.6-16.8-51.5 0-66.3 48-125.6 125.1-125.6 68.3 0 105.8 43 105.8 100.5 0 75.6-32.5 139.5-80.6 139.5-26.6 0-46.5-22.7-40.1-50.5 7.6-33.2 22.5-69.1 22.5-93 0-21.5-11.2-39.4-34.3-39.4-27.2 0-49 29-49 67.9 0 24.8 8.1 41.6 8.1 41.6S303.9 644.5 299 665.8c-9.7 42.4-1.5 94.4-.7 99.6.4 3.1 4.3 3.9 6.1 1.6 2.5-3.3 34.9-44.6 45.8-85.8 3.1-11.6 17.9-72.1 17.9-72.1 8.9 17.3 34.7 32.7 62.1 32.7 81.8 0 137.2-76.9 137.2-179.8 0-77.8-63.9-150.3-160.9-150.3-120.9 0-181.9 89.4-181.9 163.9z"/>
  <!--[if lte IE 8]>
  <foreignObject>
    <img src="../../images/svg/output/png/pinterest.png" alt="Pinterest" class="no-svg-png">
  </foreignObject>
  <![endif]-->
</svg>
</span>
      </a> <!-- /.ss-link -->
    </li> <!-- /.ss-item -->
  </ul> <!-- /.ss-list -->
</div> <!-- /.social-share -->
</div>


              </div> <!-- /.has-social -->
          </div> <!-- /.img-inner -->


        </div> <!-- /.img-wrap -->
								      </div> <!-- /.b-thumb -->
								    <div class="b-text">
								      <div class="dek text">
								        <p>Everyone talks about how to turn pumpkins and gourds into seasonal décor, but what about cornhusks? The deep purple husk is a nice finishing touch to a simple fabric wreath—and would be a pretty, seasonal embellishment on a wreath of any style. You can find cornhusks at craft stores, grocery stores, or even farmers markets.</p>
								          <p>Get the tutorial at <a href="">The Cards We Drew</a>.</p>
								      </div> <!-- /.dek -->
										</div> <!-- /.b-text -->
									</div> <!-- /.b-inner -->
								</div> <!-- /.block-listicle-item -->
								<hr class="hr--m">
								<div class="block block-listicle-item block-image-list-item">
									<div class="b-inner cf">
								    <div class="b-head">
								      <span class="number--large listicle-number">8</span>
								      <h2 class="b-title">Fall Straw Wreath</h2>
								    </div> <!-- /.b-head -->
								      <div class="b-thumb">
        <div class="img-wrap  has-credit ">
          <div class="img-inner">
              <div class="has-social">


      <img class="lazy" data-original="http://cdn-image.realsimple.com/sites/default/files/styles/rs_photo_gallery/public/straw-wreath_0.jpg?itok=MQTdUgVA" itemprop="image" alt="Echoes of Laughter" />
      <noscript><img src="http://cdn-image.realsimple.com/sites/default/files/styles/rs_photo_gallery/public/straw-wreath_0.jpg?itok=MQTdUgVA" alt="Echoes of Laughter"></noscript>




              <div class="img-overlay o-social"><div class="social-share">
  <ul class="ss-list">
    <li class="ss-item">
      <a class="ss-link" href="#">
        
        <span class="no-bg icon rounded icon-pinterest icon--big"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="146 290 500 500" enable-background="new 146 290 500 500">

</svg>
</span>
      </a> <!-- /.ss-link -->
    </li> <!-- /.ss-item -->
  </ul> <!-- /.ss-list -->
</div> <!-- /.social-share -->
</div>


              </div> <!-- /.has-social -->
          </div> <!-- /.img-inner -->

              <span class="credit">Photo by Echoes of Laughter</span>

        </div> <!-- /.img-wrap -->
								      </div> <!-- /.b-thumb -->
								    <div class="b-text">
								      <div class="dek text">
								        <p>This straw wreath (you can see it poking through the ribbon!) reminds us of our favorite parts of fall: pumpkin picking and hayrides. The off-center cluster of flowers is eye-catching without being too hectic or distracting, which is perfect for a glass window.</p>
								          <p>Get the tutorial at <a href="">Echoes of Laughter</a>.</p>
								      </div> <!-- /.dek -->
										</div> <!-- /.b-text -->
									</div> <!-- /.b-inner -->
								</div> <!-- /.block-listicle-item -->
								<hr class="hr--m">
								<div class="block block-listicle-item block-image-list-item">
									<div class="b-inner cf">
								    <div class="b-head">
								      <span class="number--large listicle-number">9</span>
								      <h2 class="b-title">Paper Wreath</h2>
								    </div> <!-- /.b-head -->
								      <div class="b-thumb">
        <div class="img-wrap ">
          <div class="img-inner">
              <div class="has-social">


      <img class="lazy" data-original="http://cdn-image.realsimple.com/sites/default/files/styles/rs_photo_gallery/public/paper-wreath.jpg?itok=elhHaicG" itemprop="image" alt="Make Life Lovely" />

          </div> <!-- /.img-inner -->


        </div> <!-- /.img-wrap -->
								      </div> <!-- /.b-thumb -->
								    <div class="b-text">
								      <div class="dek text">
								        <p>Don’t let the look of this project stress you out—the blogger used a scalloped paper punch as a shortcut, although you do have to glue them on individually. The rest of the materials are ones you probably have at home—like paper, a pencil, and a glue gun. Seriously, it’s that simple!</p>
								          <p>Get the tutorial at <a href="">Make Life Lovely</a>.</p>

              <span class="credit">Photo by Tater Tots and Jello</span>

								      </div> <!-- /.b-thumb -->
								    <div class="b-text">
								      <div class="dek text">
								        <p>Although this bright and colorful wreath is billed for Halloween, you can use different colors or patterns of tape around the lids to make it appropriate all season long. Start stocking up on old jars so that you don’t have to buy them at the store. Neighbors or friends might have old ones lying around!</p>
								          <p>Get the tutorial at <a href="">Tater Tots and Jello</a>.</p>

  <path fill="#fff" d="M605 363.9c-3.7-19.1-19.2-33.9-38.2-36.6-.8-.1-1.6-.3-2.4-.4H227.6c-2 .4-4.1.6-6.1 1.1-18.6 4.3-32.4 19.5-35 38.6-.1.8-.3 1.6-.4 2.4v342c.4 2.2.7 4.3 1.1 6.5 4.1 18.4 19.6 32.7 38.1 35.2.9.1 1.8.3 2.7.4h335.9c2.2-.4 4.4-.7 6.5-1.2 17.2-3.7 31.2-18.2 34.5-35.7.4-1.9.6-3.8.9-5.8V369.5c-.2-1.9-.5-3.7-.8-5.6zM310.9 538.7c.7-47 38.5-85.1 85.1-85 47.6 0 86 39.9 85 88.3-1 46.9-39.5 85.4-87 84.4-45.7-1.1-83.8-39.4-83.1-87.7zM560.4 501v189c0 9.1-7.7 16.9-16.7 16.9H248.2c-8.9 0-16.7-7.8-16.7-16.9V499.7h40c-10.4 36.1-7.6 70.9 10.1 104.1 11.9 22.2 29 39.5 50.7 51.9 43 24.5 96.4 22 136.9-6 15.6-10.8 28.4-24.4 38.2-40.8 9.9-16.4 15.9-34.1 18.1-53.1 2.2-19 .5-37.7-5.2-56.1h40.1v1.3zm0-81.8c0 9-7.2 16.8-16.1 17-7 .2-13.9 0-20.8.1h-19.1c-7.8 0-14.2-4.4-16.6-11.5-.6-1.9-1-4-1-5.9-.1-13.3 0-26.7 0-40 0-9.6 7.5-17.3 17-17.3h39.6c9.5 0 17 7.7 17 17.3v40.3z"/>

              Search
              Health / Nutrition

              5 Ways to Stay Cool Under Pressure

              Real Simple asked five professionals with (unusually) stressful jobs to share their best secrets for keeping a level head.

              By Sarah Robbins
              November 22, 2015
              • 2k
              • 782
              • 936
              • Save
              30

              Before a Stressful Event, Stage a Mental Dress Rehearsal

              Photo by Getty Images/ Martin Harvey of the WikiCommons and Google Images

              In surgery, you don’t have the luxury of wondering, What if this doesn’t work? It has to work. That’s why, the night before a big procedure, I run through the entire thing like a movie in my head. I also visualize what I’ll do in the event of major complications—which can make a huge difference. During a recent operation, my team encountered a problem when a hole opened in the vena cava, the largest vein in the body, during the removal of an attached tumor. It’s a terrifying situation: The person could bleed to death in minutes. But I had considered this possibility beforehand. So when the vein ruptured, I knew exactly what to do and quickly restored control. And I’m happy to report, the patient is doing fine.

              Thomas Heffernan is a cancer surgeon in Dallas.

              2

              Address the Most Urgent Need First

              During my 21 years as an air-traffic controller, I’ve had a number of unexpected things happen, from a bomb threat to a helicopter pilot telling me that he had lost his engine and needed to land right away. I always remember what a veteran controller once told me: “It’s always going to get crazy—just don’t get flustered by it. Prioritize as you go, and that way you’ll get through the decision-making process.” It’s crucial to discern between a real emergency and something that can wait. For example, a departing flight that cannot get its gear to retract is less critical than an aircraft with smoke in the cockpit. For me, safety trumps efficiency every time.

              Cherie Hitt is a supervisory air-traffic controller at the world’s busiest airport, Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International.

              3

              Listen

              You can’t succeed in improv if you go onstage and just start telling jokes. You have to be flexible and pay attention to what people are saying so a scene doesn’t go astray. When you watch talented performers, you can see that they’re committed to the reality that’s being created onstage. In moments when they might not know what to say, they lean on their fellow cast members for more information. Often the group mind is more intelligent than any one given perspective. Yes, even yours.

              Matt Walsh is a cofounder of the Upright Citizens Brigade improv sketch-comedy troupe. He lives in Los Angeles.

              4

              Know When to Take a Breather

              Sometimes during a performance, a tiger will do something potentially dangerous that’s not in the routine. When that happens, I offer verbal reassurance (“OK, calm down”), almost like you would to a pet or a toddler. If that doesn’t work, I try offering red meat (really). But if a cat becomes threatening, I leave the ring so she can relax, even if that leads to an awkward pause in the show. The idea of “the show must go on” is important in the circus community, but I’ve learned not to let that mantra dictate my behavior.

              Tabayara Maluenda is an exotic-animal trainer with Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus.

              5

              Block Out Anything Unnecessary

              Most of my pressure-filled moments come when big news breaks. On these days, there is so much information to consider that you can’t process it all fast enough to react at the speed of the market. Knowing that I have other people as a backup—to give me a market opinion or help out when I get stuck—helps me make confident, truly informed decisions. When the market starts moving really quickly, I’ll call out, “What’s going on?” My trusted team shouts information at me while I continue to trade and make decisions. Sometimes I close my eyes and breathe—just to clear my head of outside distractions. I know how to decipher my colleagues’ tone of voice and the specific words they use in order to make a lightning-quick decision. This is important, because in my line of work, there are no do-overs.

              Doreen Mogavero is the founder and the CEO of—as well as a floor broker for—Mogavero Lee & Co., a boutique brokerage firm in New York City.

              More: Health, Nutrition, Cooking

        </div> <!-- /.search-field-wrap -->
        <button class="submit t-bkg">
      <svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="175.5 -92.5 500 500" enable-background="new 175.5 -92.5 500 500">
        <title>Search</title>
        <path d="M490.1 259.9l-2.8 2.1c-33.2 24.3-74 37.7-115.1 37.7-107.8 0-195.5-87.6-195.5-195.4C176.8 52 197.1 2.9 234-34c37-36.9 86.1-57.2 138.3-57.2 107.7 0 195.4 87.7 195.4 195.5 0 40.8-13.4 81.7-37.7 115l-2.1 2.8 146.4 146.3-37.8 37.8-146.4-146.3zm-118-297.7c-37.9 0-73.5 14.8-100.4 41.7C244.8 30.7 230 66.3 230 104.3c0 78.3 63.7 142 142 142s142-63.7 142-142S450.5-37.8 372.1-37.8z"/>
        <!--[if lte IE 8]>
        <foreignObject>
          <img src="../../images/svg/output/png/magnifying-glass.png" alt="Search" class="no-svg-png">
        </foreignObject>
        <![endif]-->
      </svg>
        	<span class="is-vishidden">Search</span>
        </button> <!-- /.search-submit -->
      </fieldset>
    </form> <!-- /.search-form -->
	  </div> <!-- /.search-overlay -->

	    <div class="advertisement advertisement-responsive-leaderboard ad-blocks ad-leaderboard   ">
	      <div class="ad-block ad-300x50 js-ad-refresh"><a href=""><img src="http://cdn.creative.medialytics.com/raw_assets/servo_prod/campaigns/CA-KS2PC8D/creatives/CR-CDTH2C5/versions/1/MBAN%20UnstopablesTargetiMedia%20FreshScentspiration%20xxxx%20320x50%201415%203%20Static.jpg.jpg"></a></div>
	        <div class="ad-block ad-728x90 js-ad-refresh"><a href=""><img src="http://pagead2.googlesyndication.com/pagead/imgad?id=CICAgKDjt-P9LBABGAEyCHdr0udyiur2"></a></div>
	    </div> <!-- /.ad-leaderboard -->

	</header> <!-- .header -->
	<div class="main cf lc" role="main" aria-live="polite">
		<div class="primary">
			<section class="primary-inner">
				<article class="article article-list article-list-type" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">

						<header class="article-header cf">
							<div class="kicker dib"><a itemprop="articleSection" href="#">Health</a>  <span class="divider">/</span> <a itemprop="articleSection" href="#">Nutrition</a>  </div>
							<h1 class="lead-headline" itemprop="headline">5 Ways to Stay Cool Under Pressure</h1>
							<h2 class="lead-subtitle" itemprop="alternativeHeadline">Real Simple asked five professionals with (unusually) stressful jobs to share their best secrets for keeping a level head.</h2>
							<div class="article-meta">
								<div class="byline" itemprop="author">By <span>Sarah Robbins</span></div>
								<time class="date" datetime="2013-04-06T12:32+00:00" itemprop="datePublished" pubdate>November 22, 2015</time>
							</div> <!-- /.article-details -->
							<div class="article-tools">
								<div class="social-share">
									<ul class="ss-list">
								    <li class="ss-item">
								      <a class="ss-link" href="#">
								        <span class="ss-count">2k</span>
								        <span class="no-bg icon rounded icon-facebook icon--medium"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="146 290 500 500" enable-background="new 146 290 500 500">
  <title>Facebook</title>
  <path fill="#fff" d="M435.9 758V547h57.3l7.5-72.7h-64.8l.1-36.4c0-19 1.8-29.2 28.6-29.2h35.8V336H443c-68.9 0-93.1 35.3-93.1 94.6v43.6H307V547h43v211h85.9z"/>
  <!--[if lte IE 8]>
  <foreignObject>
    <img src="../../images/svg/output/png/facebook.png" alt="Facebook" class="no-svg-png">
  </foreignObject>
  <![endif]-->
  </svg>
</span>
								      </a> <!-- /.ss-link -->
								    </li> <!-- /.ss-item -->
								    <li class="ss-item">
								      <a class="ss-link" href="#">
								        <span class="ss-count">782</span>
								        <span class="no-bg icon rounded icon-pinterest icon--medium"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="146 290 500 500" enable-background="new 146 290 500 500">
  <title>Pinterest</title>
  <path fill="#fff" d="M224.6 475.6c0 45.1 16.6 85.2 52.1 100.3 5.8 2.5 11.1.1 12.7-6.6 1.1-4.6 4-16.3 5.2-21.1 1.8-6.6 1-8.9-3.7-14.6-10.2-12.4-16.8-28.6-16.8-51.5 0-66.3 48-125.6 125.1-125.6 68.3 0 105.8 43 105.8 100.5 0 75.6-32.5 139.5-80.6 139.5-26.6 0-46.5-22.7-40.1-50.5 7.6-33.2 22.5-69.1 22.5-93 0-21.5-11.2-39.4-34.3-39.4-27.2 0-49 29-49 67.9 0 24.8 8.1 41.6 8.1 41.6S303.9 644.5 299 665.8c-9.7 42.4-1.5 94.4-.7 99.6.4 3.1 4.3 3.9 6.1 1.6 2.5-3.3 34.9-44.6 45.8-85.8 3.1-11.6 17.9-72.1 17.9-72.1 8.9 17.3 34.7 32.7 62.1 32.7 81.8 0 137.2-76.9 137.2-179.8 0-77.8-63.9-150.3-160.9-150.3-120.9 0-181.9 89.4-181.9 163.9z"/>

  <path fill="#fff" d="M389.9 458.5l.9 15-15.2-1.8c-55.4-7.1-103.8-31.1-145-71.3l-20.1-20-5.2 14.7c-11 32.9-4 67.7 18.9 91 12.1 12.9 9.4 14.8-11.6 7.1-7.3-2.4-13.7-4.3-14.3-3.4-2.1 2.2 5.2 30.1 11 41.2 7.9 15.4 24.1 30.4 41.8 39.4l14.9 7-17.7.3c-17.1 0-17.7.3-15.8 6.8 6.1 20 30.2 41.2 57 50.4l18.9 6.4-16.5 9.8c-24.4 14.1-53 22.1-81.6 22.7-13.7.3-25 1.5-25 2.5 0 3.1 37.2 20.3 58.8 27.1 64.9 20 141.9 11.4 199.8-22.8 41.1-24.3 82.2-72.6 101.4-119.3 10.3-24.9 20.7-70.4 20.7-92.2 0-14.1.9-16 18-32.9 10.1-9.8 19.5-20.6 21.3-23.7 3-5.8 2.7-5.8-12.8-.6-25.9 9.2-29.6 8-16.8-5.8 9.5-9.9 20.7-27.7 20.7-32.9 0-.9-4.6.6-9.7 3.4-5.5 3.1-17.7 7.7-26.8 10.5l-16.5 5.2-14.9-10.2c-8.2-5.5-19.8-11.7-25.9-13.5-15.5-4.3-39.3-3.7-53.3 1.2-38.1 14-62.1 49.6-59.4 88.7z"/>

							</div> <!-- /.article-tools -->
						</header> <!-- /.article-header -->

					<div class="ad-block ad-300x250 block center hide-med hide-large hide-larger space-double-btm">
						<a href=""><img src="http://s1.2mdn.net/viewad/4579100/300x250_Brand_Banner.jpg"></a>
					</div> <!-- /.ad-300x250 -->

					<section class="section article-body" itemprop="articleBody">
						<div class="listicle soft-red">
								<div class="block block-listicle-item block-article-list-item">
									<div class="b-inner cf">
								    <div class="b-head">
								      <span class="number--large listicle-number double-digit">30</span>
								      <h2 class="b-title">Before a Stressful Event, Stage a Mental Dress Rehearsal</h2>
								    </div> <!-- /.b-head -->
								      <div class="b-thumb">
        <div class="img-wrap  has-credit ">
          <div class="img-inner">
              <div class="has-social">


      <img class="lazy" data-original="http://cdn-image.realsimple.com/sites/default/files/styles/rs_main_image/public/image/images/0111/airplane-sunset_300.jpg?itok=ypMO-5N0" itemprop="image" alt="Before a Stressful Event, Stage a Mental Dress Rehearsal" />
      <noscript><img src="http://cdn-image.realsimple.com/sites/default/files/styles/rs_main_image/public/image/images/0111/airplane-sunset_300.jpg?itok=ypMO-5N0" alt="Before a Stressful Event, Stage a Mental Dress Rehearsal"></noscript>




              <div class="img-overlay o-social"><div class="social-share">
  <ul class="ss-list">
    <li class="ss-item">
      <a class="ss-link" href="#">
        
        <span class="no-bg icon rounded icon-pinterest icon--big"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="146 290 500 500" enable-background="new 146 290 500 500">
  <title>Pinterest</title>
  <path fill="#fff" d="M224.6 475.6c0 45.1 16.6 85.2 52.1 100.3 5.8 2.5 11.1.1 12.7-6.6 1.1-4.6 4-16.3 5.2-21.1 1.8-6.6 1-8.9-3.7-14.6-10.2-12.4-16.8-28.6-16.8-51.5 0-66.3 48-125.6 125.1-125.6 68.3 0 105.8 43 105.8 100.5 0 75.6-32.5 139.5-80.6 139.5-26.6 0-46.5-22.7-40.1-50.5 7.6-33.2 22.5-69.1 22.5-93 0-21.5-11.2-39.4-34.3-39.4-27.2 0-49 29-49 67.9 0 24.8 8.1 41.6 8.1 41.6S303.9 644.5 299 665.8c-9.7 42.4-1.5 94.4-.7 99.6.4 3.1 4.3 3.9 6.1 1.6 2.5-3.3 34.9-44.6 45.8-85.8 3.1-11.6 17.9-72.1 17.9-72.1 8.9 17.3 34.7 32.7 62.1 32.7 81.8 0 137.2-76.9 137.2-179.8 0-77.8-63.9-150.3-160.9-150.3-120.9 0-181.9 89.4-181.9 163.9z"/>
  <!--[if lte IE 8]>
  <foreignObject>
    <img src="../../images/svg/output/png/pinterest.png" alt="Pinterest" class="no-svg-png">
  </foreignObject>
  <![endif]-->
</svg>
</span>
      </a> <!-- /.ss-link -->
    </li> <!-- /.ss-item -->
  </ul> <!-- /.ss-list -->
</div> <!-- /.social-share -->
</div>


              </div> <!-- /.has-social -->
          </div> <!-- /.img-inner -->

              <span class="credit">Photo by Getty Images/ Martin Harvey of the WikiCommons and Google Images</span>

        </div> <!-- /.img-wrap -->
								      </div> <!-- /.b-thumb -->
								    <div class="b-text">
								      <div class="dek text">
								        <p>In surgery, you don’t have the luxury of wondering, <a href=''>What if this doesn’t work?</a> It has to work. That’s why, the night before a big procedure, I run through the entire thing like a movie in my head. I also visualize what I’ll do in the event of major complications—which can make a huge difference. During a recent operation, my team encountered a problem when a hole opened in the vena cava, the largest vein in the body, during the removal of an attached tumor. It’s a terrifying situation: The person could bleed to death in minutes. But I had considered this possibility beforehand. So when the vein ruptured, I knew exactly what to do and quickly restored control. And I’m happy to report, the patient is doing fine.</p><p>Thomas Heffernan is a cancer surgeon in Dallas.</p>
								      </div> <!-- /.dek -->
										</div> <!-- /.b-text -->
									</div> <!-- /.b-inner -->
								</div> <!-- /.block-listicle-item -->
								<div class="block block-listicle-item block-article-list-item block--no-img">
									<div class="b-inner cf">
								    <div class="b-head">
								      <span class="number--large listicle-number">2</span>
								      <h2 class="b-title">Address the Most Urgent Need First</h2>
								    </div> <!-- /.b-head -->
								    <div class="b-text">
								      <div class="dek text">
								        <p>During my 21 years as an air-traffic controller, I’ve had a number of unexpected things happen, from a bomb threat to a helicopter pilot telling me that he had lost his engine and needed to land right away. I always remember what a veteran controller once told me: “It’s always going to get crazy—just don’t get flustered by it. Prioritize as you go, and that way you’ll get through the decision-making process.” It’s crucial to discern between a real emergency and something that can wait. For example, a departing flight that cannot get its gear to retract is less critical than an aircraft with smoke in the cockpit. For me, safety trumps efficiency every time.</p><p>Cherie Hitt is a supervisory air-traffic controller at the world’s busiest airport, Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International.</p>
								      </div> <!-- /.dek -->
										</div> <!-- /.b-text -->
									</div> <!-- /.b-inner -->
								</div> <!-- /.block-listicle-item -->
								<div class="block block-listicle-item block-article-list-item block--no-img">
									<div class="b-inner cf">
								    <div class="b-head">
								      <span class="number--large listicle-number">3</span>
								      <h2 class="b-title">Listen</h2>
								    </div> <!-- /.b-head -->
								    <div class="b-text">
								      <div class="dek text">
								        <p>You can’t succeed in improv if you go onstage and just start telling jokes. You have to be flexible and pay attention to what people are saying so a scene doesn’t go astray. When you watch talented performers, you can see that they’re committed to the reality that’s being created onstage. In moments when they might not know what to say, they lean on their fellow cast members for more information. Often the group mind is more intelligent than any one given perspective. Yes, even yours.</p><p>Matt Walsh is a cofounder of the Upright Citizens Brigade improv sketch-comedy troupe. He lives in Los Angeles.</p>
								      </div> <!-- /.dek -->
										</div> <!-- /.b-text -->
									</div> <!-- /.b-inner -->
								</div> <!-- /.block-listicle-item -->

							<hr class="hr--s">

							<div class="ad-blocks ad-responsive ad-instream">
								<div class="ad-block ad-300x250 hide-larger"><a href=""><img src="http://dqckmuwjiytix.cloudfront.net/a/8933/img/300x250_Free%20Sample_static.jpg"></a></div>
								<div class="ad-block ad-728x90 hide-large hide-med hide-small"><a href=""><img src="http://s1.2mdn.net/viewad/3340030/clx_clb_e40024_value-oxi_rev_728x90.jpg"></a></div>
							</div> <!-- /.ad-responsive -->

							<hr class="hr--l">

								<div class="block block-listicle-item block-article-list-item block--no-img">
									<div class="b-inner cf">
								    <div class="b-head">
								      <span class="number--large listicle-number">4</span>
								      <h2 class="b-title">Know When to Take a Breather</h2>
								    </div> <!-- /.b-head -->
								    <div class="b-text">
								      <div class="dek text">
								        <p>Sometimes during a performance, a tiger will do something potentially dangerous that’s not in the routine. When that happens, I offer verbal reassurance (“OK, calm down”), almost like you would to a pet or a toddler. If that doesn’t work, I try offering red meat (really). But if a cat becomes threatening, I leave the ring so she can relax, even if that leads to an awkward pause in the show. The idea of “the show must go on” is important in the circus community, but I’ve learned not to let that mantra dictate my behavior.</p><p>Tabayara Maluenda is an exotic-animal trainer with Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus.</p>
								      </div> <!-- /.dek -->
										</div> <!-- /.b-text -->
									</div> <!-- /.b-inner -->
								</div> <!-- /.block-listicle-item -->
								<div class="block block-listicle-item block-article-list-item block--no-img">
									<div class="b-inner cf">
								    <div class="b-head">
								      <span class="number--large listicle-number">5</span>
								      <h2 class="b-title">Block Out Anything Unnecessary</h2>
								    </div> <!-- /.b-head -->
								    <div class="b-text">
								      <div class="dek text">
								        <p>Most of my pressure-filled moments come when big news breaks. On these days, there is so much information to consider that you can’t process it all fast enough to react at the speed of the market. Knowing that I have other people as a backup—to give me a market opinion or help out when I get stuck—helps me make confident, truly informed decisions. When the market starts moving really quickly, I’ll call out, “What’s going on?” My trusted team shouts information at me while I continue to trade and make decisions. Sometimes I close my eyes and breathe—just to clear my head of outside distractions. I know how to decipher my colleagues’ tone of voice and the specific words they use in order to make a lightning-quick decision. This is important, because in my line of work, there are no do-overs.</p><p>Doreen Mogavero is the founder and the CEO of—as well as a floor broker for—Mogavero Lee & Co., a boutique brokerage firm in New York City.</p>
								      </div> <!-- /.dek -->
										</div> <!-- /.b-text -->
									</div> <!-- /.b-inner -->
								</div> <!-- /.block-listicle-item -->

						</div> <!-- /.listicle -->

					</section> <!-- /.article-body -->

				</article> <!-- /.article-list -->

				<div class="more-links">
				  <span class="upper space-half-r">More:</span> <a href="">Health</a>, <a href="">Nutrition</a>, <a href="">Cooking</a>
				</div> <!-- /.more-links -->

      <div class="gi">

              Beauty / Daily Finds

              6 Great Unisex Products You Might Just Fight Over

              While we may borrow from the boys to get dressed (button-downs, cardigans), guys often borrow from us girls to get groomed. Luckily, these six products are made to share.

              By Jenny Jin
              October 7, 2014
              • 2k
              • 782
              • 936
              • Save
              1

              Malin + Goetz Peppermint Shampoo

              This mild sudser has natural peppermint extract that feels cool and tingly on your scalp. And no worries about stripping strands of color: The gentle formula favors amino acid–based cleansing agents over harsh detergents so you can lather up daily.

              Get the $20, malinandgoetz.com.

              2

              Barbasol Thick & Rich Original Shaving Cream

              This rich foam has been a shower staple for more than 90 years, tackling everything from unruly beards to sensitive, nick-prone spots (we’re looking at you, ankles!). And at $2 a can, it gives you a more luxurious shave than your bar soap for about the same price.

              Get the $2, at drugstores.

              Photo by barbasol.com
              3

              Jack Black Epic Moisture Clean Cream Body Wash

              With hydrating argan oil and shea butter, this creamy cleanser gently removes grime without drying, leaving you with skin that’s superbly soft, not slick.

              Get the $26, nordstrom.com.

              Photo by nordstrom.com
              4

              Kiehl’s Facial Fuel No-Shine Moisturizing Lip Balm

              This is the most basic, no-frills lip balm there is, and we mean that in the best way possible. Packed with moisturizing heavy-hitters such as squalane, shea butter, and jojoba butter, it has a smooth, slightly waxy consistency that keeps lips supple but gives them zero color or shine.

              Get the $9, kiehls.com.

              5

              Marvis Whitening Mint Toothpaste

              Perhaps it’s the apothecary-style packaging that makes squeezing this Italian import so satisfying­—or maybe it’s the refreshing mint flavor? Either way, the fluoride-fortified paste keeps gums healthy and teeth sparkling.

              Get the $13.50, beauty.com.

              6

              Clinique Dramatically Different Moisturizing Gel

              This lightweight gel glides on and sinks into skin for an immediate plumping effect. A formula that’s oil-free and noncomedogenic ensures that you won’t wake up to an unexpected spot on your face.

              Get the $26, clinique.com.

								    <div class="b-text">
								      <div class="dek text">
								        <p>This mild sudser has natural peppermint extract that feels cool and tingly on your scalp. And no worries about stripping strands of color: The gentle formula favors amino acid–based cleansing agents over harsh detergents so you can lather up daily.</p>

          <div class="img-inner">
              <div class="has-social">

              Beauty / Daily Finds

              6 Great Unisex Products You Might Just Fight Over

              While we may borrow from the boys to get dressed (button-downs, cardigans), guys often borrow from us girls to get groomed. Luckily, these six products are made to share.

              By Jenny Jin
              October 7, 2014
              • 2k
              • 782
              • 936
              • Save
              1

              Malin + Goetz Peppermint Shampoo

              This mild sudser has natural peppermint extract that feels cool and tingly on your scalp. And no worries about stripping strands of color: The gentle formula favors amino acid–based cleansing agents over harsh detergents so you can lather up daily.

              Get the $20, malinandgoetz.com.

              2

              Barbasol Thick & Rich Original Shaving Cream

              This rich foam has been a shower staple for more than 90 years, tackling everything from unruly beards to sensitive, nick-prone spots (we’re looking at you, ankles!). And at $2 a can, it gives you a more luxurious shave than your bar soap for about the same price.

              Get the $2, at drugstores.

              Photo by barbasol.com
              3

              Jack Black Epic Moisture Clean Cream Body Wash

              With hydrating argan oil and shea butter, this creamy cleanser gently removes grime without drying, leaving you with skin that’s superbly soft, not slick.

              Get the $26, nordstrom.com.

              Photo by nordstrom.com
              4

              Kiehl’s Facial Fuel No-Shine Moisturizing Lip Balm

              This is the most basic, no-frills lip balm there is, and we mean that in the best way possible. Packed with moisturizing heavy-hitters such as squalane, shea butter, and jojoba butter, it has a smooth, slightly waxy consistency that keeps lips supple but gives them zero color or shine.

              Get the $9, kiehls.com.

              5

              Marvis Whitening Mint Toothpaste

              Perhaps it’s the apothecary-style packaging that makes squeezing this Italian import so satisfying­—or maybe it’s the refreshing mint flavor? Either way, the fluoride-fortified paste keeps gums healthy and teeth sparkling.

              Get the $13.50, beauty.com.

              6

              Clinique Dramatically Different Moisturizing Gel

              This lightweight gel glides on and sinks into skin for an immediate plumping effect. A formula that’s oil-free and noncomedogenic ensures that you won’t wake up to an unexpected spot on your face.

              Get the $26, clinique.com.

              Daily Finds Newsletter

              Get new daily finds delivered to your inbox!

              privacy policy
              Home / Daily Finds

              6 Helpful Holiday Storage Containers

              When the holidays come to a close, it’s (unfortunately) also time to tackle the clean up. Turn to these vessels to keep your seasonal décor safely contained until next year.

              By Jessica Fecteau
              December 12, 2014
              • 2k
              • 782
              • 936
              • Save
              1

              Quilted Red Wreath Bag

              You won’t be left guessing which decoration sits within this storage bag thanks to the convenient see-through panel. The 24-inch bag fits the average wreath and has interior clips to make sure everything stays in place.

              Get the $20, crateandbarrel.com.

              2

              Ornament Storage Chest

              Store up to 54 ornaments in this three-drawer case that comes with handles on the sides for easy transport from the attic to the tree.

              Get the $2, at stacksandstacks.com.

              Photo by barbasol.com
              3

              Real Simple® Holiday Gift Wrap Under Bed Wrapping Paper Storage

              Corral all your holiday wrapping supplies within this festive, soft-sided box. With pockets for bows and bags, slots for ribbon spools, and a section for rolls a-plenty, everything you need will be right at hand.

              Get the $26, bedbathandbeyond.com.

              Photo by nordstrom.com
              4

              Seasons Holiday Tree Rolling Storage Duffel

              Taking down the artificial tree is only half the battle. Make storing it a snap with this wheeled bag equipped with adjustable straps, buckles and a padded exterior.

              Get the $119, homedepot.com.

              5

              Holiday Dinner Plate Storage Box

              Stow away your extra party plates or even fine china until next year’s holiday feast in this protective carrier. It even folds flat while your plates are in use during the season.

              Get the $13.50, organizeit.com.

              6

              Holiday 4-Drawer Storage Chest

              At just over two feet tall, this unit can hold up to 32 ornaments within the four slotted drawers. Organize them by color or type (heirloom, decorative, fragile) to make decorating the tree a hassle-free event next year.

              Get the $126, kohls.com.

								        <p>This mild sudser has natural peppermint extract that feels cool and tingly on your scalp. And no worries about stripping strands of color: The gentle formula favors amino acid–based cleansing agents over harsh detergents so you can lather up daily.</p>

</svg>
</span>
      </a> <!-- /.ss-link -->
    </li> <!-- /.ss-item -->
  </ul> <!-- /.ss-list -->

              </div> <!-- /.has-social -->
          </div> <!-- /.img-inner -->


        </div> <!-- /.img-wrap -->
								      </div> <!-- /.b-thumb -->
								    <div class="b-text">

								        <p>This rich foam has been a shower staple for more than 90 years, tackling everything from unruly beards to sensitive, nick-prone spots (we’re looking at you, ankles!). And at $2 a can, it gives you a more luxurious shave than your bar soap for about the same price.</p>
								          <p>Get the <strong>$2</strong>, at drugstores.</p>

										<div class="kicker dib"><a itemprop="articleSection" href="#">Home</a>  <span class="divider">/</span> <a itemprop="articleSection" href="#">Daily Finds</a>  </div>
										<h1 class="lead-headline" itemprop="headline">6 Helpful Holiday Storage Containers</h1>
										<h2 class="lead-subtitle" itemprop="alternativeHeadline">When the holidays come to a close, it’s (unfortunately) also time to tackle the clean up. Turn to these vessels to keep your seasonal décor safely contained until next year.</h2>
										<div class="article-meta">
											<div class="byline" itemprop="author">By <span>Jessica Fecteau</span></div>
											<time class="date" datetime="2013-04-06T12:32+00:00" itemprop="datePublished" pubdate>December 12, 2014</time>
										</div> <!-- /.article-details -->

  <![endif]-->
</svg>
</span>
      </a> <!-- /.ss-link -->
    </li> <!-- /.ss-item -->
  </ul> <!-- /.ss-list -->
</div> <!-- /.social-share -->
</div>


              </div> <!-- /.has-social -->
          </div> <!-- /.img-inner -->


        </div> <!-- /.img-wrap -->
											      </div> <!-- /.b-thumb -->
											    <div class="b-text">
											      <div class="dek text">
											        <p>At just over two feet tall, this unit can hold up to 32 ornaments within the four slotted drawers. Organize them by color or type (heirloom, decorative, fragile) to make decorating the tree a hassle-free event next year.</p>
											          <p>Get the <strong>$126</strong>, <a href="">kohls.com</a>.</p>
											      </div> <!-- /.dek -->
													</div> <!-- /.b-text -->
												</div> <!-- /.b-inner -->
											</div> <!-- /.block-listicle-item -->

									</div> <!-- /.listicle -->
								</section> <!-- /.article-body -->
							</article> <!-- /.gallery -->

					</section> <!-- /.article-body -->

				</article> <!-- /.gallery -->

				<div class="more-links">
				  <span class="upper space-half-r">More:</span> <a href="">Health</a>, <a href="">Nutrition</a>, <a href="">Cooking</a>

</li>
    </ol> <!-- /.block-list -->
  </section> <!-- /.most-shared -->
			  <div class="ad-block ad-sub-offer block js-ad-refresh">
			    <a href=""><img src="http://pagead2.googlesyndication.com/simgad/15229186113044141373"></a>

              Health / Nutrition

              5 Healthy Reasons to Eat an Apple Today

              As if you needed one more excuse to go apple picking this season—the classic fruit comes with a host of health benefits.

              By Abigail Wise
              April 22, 2015
              • 2k
              • 782
              • 936
              • Save

              As it turns out, an apple a day really may keep the doctor away. From fighting obesity to strengthening your mind, this juicy, seasonal fruit comes with some serious health perks.

              Apples may keep obesity at bay.

              A new study from Washington State University found that some of the compounds in Granny Smiths, in particular, could help prevent certain disorders that lead to obesity. The sour fruit helps good bacteria in the colon grow and eventually spread to the stomach. And a healthy metabolism relies on the right amount of bacteria, which can affect inflammation levels and help us feel full and satisfied. While the nondigestible compounds responsible for these benefits can be found in other types of apples, Granny Smiths contain the most.

              You may want to skip peeling your apples if you’re after the full slimming effects. Researchers at the University of Iowa linked ursolic acid, found in the peel, with a lower rate of obesity in mice. That’s because the compound seems to increase brown fat, the “good fat” that regulates your body temperature and appears to feed on regular body fat.

              Buttermilk Biscuits

              Strawberry Buttermilk
              Smoothie

              Buttermilk, Banana, and
              Honey Ice Pops

              Buttermilk Fried
              Chicken

              Garlicky Buttermilk
              Dressing

              Buttermilk Mashed
              Potatoes

              Apples could fight cancer.

              An apple provides roughly 10 percent of the vitamin C and fiber we need each day. Vitamin C is great for boosting our immune system and has been linked with a lower risk of cancer in the esophagus. And dietary fiber is thought to reduce the risk of colorectal cancer, possibly because it helps with weight control. The peels of apples also contain quercetin, a flavonoid that shows anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties, which can help prevent cancer.

              They lower cholesterol.

              As a great source of fiber, apples are classic cholesterol busters. That’s because pectin, one type of soluble fiber, lowers LDL, or the “bad cholesterol.” A medium-sized apple packs 4.4 grams of fiber, a good chunk of the 21 to 25 grams recommended for women and the 30 to 38 grams recommended for men each day.

              They lower cholesterol.

              As a great source of fiber, apples are classic cholesterol busters. That’s because pectin, one type of soluble fiber, lowers LDL, or the “bad cholesterol.” A medium-sized apple packs 4.4 grams of fiber, a good chunk of the 21 to 25 grams recommended for women and the 30 to 38 grams recommended for men each day.

              They lower cholesterol.

              As a great source of fiber, apples are classic cholesterol busters. That’s because pectin, one type of soluble fiber, lowers LDL, or the “bad cholesterol.” A medium-sized apple packs 4.4 grams of fiber, a good chunk of the 21 to 25 grams recommended for women and the 30 to 38 grams recommended for men each day.

              And they might reduce the risk of stroke.

              White, fleshy fruits, like apples, may help lower the odds of having a stroke. One study showed that people who ate a lot of white fruits and veggies were able to reduce their stroke risk by 50 percent. Even adding as little as 25 grams of white produce in each day could lower your risk of stroke by nine percent. So munch away on those apples, pears and cauliflower.

              Apples are food for thought.

              Apples may increase your brainpower. Although the rumor that an apple has as much caffeine as a cup of coffee is definitely a myth, they do contain natural sugars that can also give you a boost. So go ahead and try subbing out that second cup of coffee for an apple this afternoon.

              More: Health, Nutrition, Cooking

              Follow Real Simple

						<header class="article-header  cf">
							<div class="kicker dib"><a itemprop="articleSection" href="#">Health</a>  <span class="divider">/</span> <a itemprop="articleSection" href="#">Nutrition</a>  </div>
 
							<h1 class="lead-headline" itemprop="headline">5 Healthy Reasons to Eat an Apple Today</h1>
								<h2 class="lead-subtitle" itemprop="alternativeHeadline">As if you needed one more excuse to go apple picking this season—the classic fruit comes with a host of health benefits.</h2>
								<div class="article-meta">
									<div class="byline" itemprop="author">By <span>Abigail Wise</span></div>
									<time class="date" datetime="2013-04-06T12:32+00:00" itemprop="datePublished" pubdate>April 22, 2015</time>

							    <figure class="figure figure--l figure--right">
      <div class="img-wrap  has-credit ">
        <div class="img-inner">
            <div class="has-social">


      <img class="lazy" data-original="http://cdn-image.realsimple.com/sites/default/files/styles/rs_photo_gallery/public/image/images/1401/pistachio-fig_300_0.jpg?itok=MMXSUOYC" itemprop="image" alt="Apples" />
      <noscript><img src="http://cdn-image.realsimple.com/sites/default/files/styles/rs_photo_gallery/public/image/images/1401/pistachio-fig_300_0.jpg?itok=MMXSUOYC" alt="Apples"></noscript>




            <div class="img-overlay o-social"><div class="social-share">
  <ul class="ss-list">
    <li class="ss-item">
      <a class="ss-link" href="#">
        
        <span class="no-bg icon rounded icon-pinterest icon--big"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="146 290 500 500" enable-background="new 146 290 500 500">
  <title>Pinterest</title>
  <path fill="#fff" d="M224.6 475.6c0 45.1 16.6 85.2 52.1 100.3 5.8 2.5 11.1.1 12.7-6.6 1.1-4.6 4-16.3 5.2-21.1 1.8-6.6 1-8.9-3.7-14.6-10.2-12.4-16.8-28.6-16.8-51.5 0-66.3 48-125.6 125.1-125.6 68.3 0 105.8 43 105.8 100.5 0 75.6-32.5 139.5-80.6 139.5-26.6 0-46.5-22.7-40.1-50.5 7.6-33.2 22.5-69.1 22.5-93 0-21.5-11.2-39.4-34.3-39.4-27.2 0-49 29-49 67.9 0 24.8 8.1 41.6 8.1 41.6S303.9 644.5 299 665.8c-9.7 42.4-1.5 94.4-.7 99.6.4 3.1 4.3 3.9 6.1 1.6 2.5-3.3 34.9-44.6 45.8-85.8 3.1-11.6 17.9-72.1 17.9-72.1 8.9 17.3 34.7 32.7 62.1 32.7 81.8 0 137.2-76.9 137.2-179.8 0-77.8-63.9-150.3-160.9-150.3-120.9 0-181.9 89.4-181.9 163.9z"/>
  <!--[if lte IE 8]>
  <foreignObject>
    <img src="../../images/svg/output/png/pinterest.png" alt="Pinterest" class="no-svg-png">
  </foreignObject>
  <![endif]-->
</svg>
</span>
      </a> <!-- /.ss-link -->
    </li> <!-- /.ss-item -->
  </ul> <!-- /.ss-list -->
</div> <!-- /.social-share -->
</div>


            </div> <!-- /.has-social -->
        </div> <!-- /.img-inner -->

            <span class="credit">Photo by Sean Gallup/Getty Images</span>

          <figcaption class="caption">In addition to tasting good, apples may increase your brainpower.</figcaption>
      </div> <!-- /.img-wrap -->
							    </figure> <!-- /.figure -->

							<p>As it turns out, an apple a day really may keep the doctor away. From fighting obesity to strengthening your mind, this juicy, seasonal fruit comes with some serious health perks.</p>

							<h2>Apples may keep obesity at bay.</h2>
							<p>A new study from Washington State University found that some of the compounds in Granny Smiths, in particular, could help prevent certain disorders that lead to obesity. The sour fruit helps good bacteria in the colon grow and eventually spread to the stomach. And a healthy metabolism relies on the right amount of bacteria, which can affect inflammation levels and help us feel full and satisfied.  While the nondigestible compounds responsible for these benefits can be found in other types of apples, Granny Smiths contain the most.</p>

							<p>You may want to skip peeling your apples if you’re after the full slimming effects. Researchers at the University of Iowa linked ursolic acid, found in the peel, with a lower rate of obesity in mice. That’s because the compound seems to increase brown fat, the “good fat” that regulates your body temperature and appears to feed on regular body fat.</p>

							<table border="1" bordercolor="#ffffff" width="100%"><tbody><tr><td align="center" valign="center"><a href="http://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/browse-all-recipes/buttermilk-biscuits"><img align="center" alt="Buttermilk Biscuits" src="http://cdn-image.realsimple.com/sites/default/files/styles/rs_main_image/public/1431618647/buttermilk-biscuits.jpg" width="250" data-loaded="true"></a></td>
							      <td align="center" valign="center"><a href="http://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/browse-all-recipes/strawberry-buttermilk-smoothie"><img alt="Strawberry Buttermilk Smoothie" src="http://cdn-image.realsimple.com/sites/default/files/styles/rs_main_image/public/1431618647/buttermilk-smoothie.jpg" width="250" data-loaded="true"></a></td>
							      <td align="center" valign="center"><a href="http://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/browse-all-recipes/buttermilk-banana-honey-ice-pops"><img alt="Buttermilk, Banana, and Honey Ice Pops" src="http://cdn-image.realsimple.com/sites/default/files/styles/rs_main_image/public/1431618647/buttermilk-pops.jpg" width="250" data-loaded="true"></a></td>
							    </tr><tr><td align="center" valign="top">
							      <h4 align="center"><a href="http://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/browse-all-recipes/buttermilk-biscuits">Buttermilk Biscuits</a></h4>
							      </td>
							      <td align="center" valign="top">
							      <h4 align="center"><a href="http://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/browse-all-recipes/strawberry-buttermilk-smoothie">Strawberry Buttermilk<br>
							      Smoothie</a></h4>
							      </td>
							      <td align="center" valign="top">
							      <h4 align="center"><a href="http://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/browse-all-recipes/buttermilk-banana-honey-ice-pops">Buttermilk, Banana, and<br>
							      Honey Ice Pops</a></h4>
							      </td>
							    </tr><tr><td align="center" valign="center"><a href="http://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/browse-all-recipes/buttermilk-fried-chicken"><img alt="Buttermilk Fried Chicken" src="http://cdn-image.realsimple.com/sites/default/files/styles/rs_main_image/public/1431618647/buttermilk-chicken.jpg" width="250" data-loaded="true"></a></td>
							      <td align="center" valign="center"><a href="http://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/browse-all-recipes/garlicky-buttermilk-dressing"><img alt="Garlicky Buttermilk Dressing" src="http://cdn-image.realsimple.com/sites/default/files/styles/rs_main_image/public/1431618647/buttermilk-dressing.jpg" width="250" data-loaded="true"></a></td>
							      <td align="center" valign="center"><a href="http://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/browse-all-recipes/buttermilk-mashed-yukon-gold-potatoes"><img alt="Buttermilk Mashed Potatoes" src="http://cdn-image.realsimple.com/sites/default/files/styles/rs_main_image/public/1431618647/buttermilk-potatoes.jpg" width="250" data-loaded="true"></a></td>
							    </tr><tr><td align="center" valign="top">
							      <h4 align="center"><a href="http://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/browse-all-recipes/buttermilk-fried-chicken">Buttermilk Fried<br>
							      Chicken</a></h4>
							      </td>
							      <td align="center" valign="top">
							      <h4 align="center"><a href="http://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/browse-all-recipes/garlicky-buttermilk-dressing">Garlicky Buttermilk<br>
							      Dressing</a></h4>
							      </td>
							      <td align="center" valign="top">
							      <h4 align="center"><a href="http://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/browse-all-recipes/buttermilk-mashed-yukon-gold-potatoes">Buttermilk Mashed<br>
							      Potatoes</a></h4>
							      </td>
							    </tr></tbody></table>

							<h2>Apples could fight cancer.</h2>
							<p>An apple provides roughly 10 percent of the vitamin C and fiber we need each day. Vitamin C is great for boosting our immune system and has been linked with a lower risk of cancer in the esophagus. And dietary fiber is thought to reduce the risk of colorectal cancer, possibly because it helps with weight control. The peels of apples also contain quercetin, a flavonoid that shows anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties, which can help prevent cancer.</p>

							<h2>They lower cholesterol.</h2>
							<p>As a great source of fiber, apples are classic cholesterol busters. That’s because pectin, one type of soluble fiber, lowers LDL, or the “bad cholesterol.” A medium-sized apple packs 4.4 grams of fiber, a good chunk of the 21 to 25 grams recommended for women and the 30 to 38 grams recommended for men each day.</p>

							<h3>They lower cholesterol.</h3>
							<p>As a great source of fiber, apples are classic cholesterol busters. That’s because pectin, one type of soluble fiber, lowers LDL, or the “bad cholesterol.” A medium-sized apple packs 4.4 grams of fiber, a good chunk of the 21 to 25 grams recommended for women and the 30 to 38 grams recommended for men each day.</p>

							<h4>They lower cholesterol.</h4>
							<p>As a great source of fiber, apples are classic cholesterol busters. That’s because pectin, one type of soluble fiber, lowers LDL, or the “bad cholesterol.” A medium-sized apple packs 4.4 grams of fiber, a good chunk of the 21 to 25 grams recommended for women and the 30 to 38 grams recommended for men each day.</p>

							<h2>And they might reduce the risk of stroke.</h2>
							<p>White, fleshy fruits, like apples, may help lower the odds of having a stroke. One study showed that people who ate a lot of white fruits and veggies were able to reduce their stroke risk by 50 percent. Even adding as little as 25 grams of white produce in each day could lower your risk of stroke by nine percent. So munch away on those apples, pears and cauliflower.</p>

							<h2>Apples are food for thought.</h2>
							<p>Apples may increase your brainpower. Although the rumor that an apple has as much caffeine as a cup of coffee is definitely a myth, they do contain natural sugars that can also give you a boost. So go ahead and try subbing out that second cup of coffee for an apple this afternoon.</p>
					</section> <!-- /.article-body -->


				</article> <!-- /.article-standard -->

					<div class="more-links">
					  <span class="upper space-half-r">More:</span> <a href="">Health</a>, <a href="">Nutrition</a>, <a href="">Cooking</a>
					</div> <!-- /.more-links -->

    <h3 class="alt-heading center">Real Simple Digital Products</h3>

              Search
              Life / Organizing

              Amazing Living Room Makeovers

              Discover the inspiring transformation of this stylish living room

              By Suzanne Sugarbaker
              April 22, 2015
              • 2k
              • 782
              • 936
              • Save

              As it turns out, an apple a day really may keep the doctor away. From fighting obesity to strengthening your mind, this juicy, seasonal fruit comes with some serious health perks.

              Apples may keep obesity at bay.

              A new study from Washington State University found that some of the compounds in Granny Smiths, in particular, could help prevent certain disorders that lead to obesity. The sour fruit helps good bacteria in the colon grow and eventually spread to the stomach. And a healthy metabolism relies on the right amount of bacteria, which can affect inflammation levels and help us feel full and satisfied. While the nondigestible compounds responsible for these benefits can be found in other types of apples, Granny Smiths contain the most.

              You may want to skip peeling your apples if you’re after the full slimming effects. Researchers at the University of Iowa linked ursolic acid, found in the peel, with a lower rate of obesity in mice. That’s because the compound seems to increase brown fat, the “good fat” that regulates your body temperature and appears to feed on regular body fat.

              Buttermilk Biscuits

              Strawberry Buttermilk
              Smoothie

              Buttermilk, Banana, and
              Honey Ice Pops

              Buttermilk Fried
              Chicken

              Garlicky Buttermilk
              Dressing

              Buttermilk Mashed
              Potatoes

              Apples could fight cancer.

              An apple provides roughly 10 percent of the vitamin C and fiber we need each day. Vitamin C is great for boosting our immune system and has been linked with a lower risk of cancer in the esophagus. And dietary fiber is thought to reduce the risk of colorectal cancer, possibly because it helps with weight control. The peels of apples also contain quercetin, a flavonoid that shows anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties, which can help prevent cancer.

              They lower cholesterol.

              As a great source of fiber, apples are classic cholesterol busters. That’s because pectin, one type of soluble fiber, lowers LDL, or the “bad cholesterol.” A medium-sized apple packs 4.4 grams of fiber, a good chunk of the 21 to 25 grams recommended for women and the 30 to 38 grams recommended for men each day.

              They lower cholesterol.

              As a great source of fiber, apples are classic cholesterol busters. That’s because pectin, one type of soluble fiber, lowers LDL, or the “bad cholesterol.” A medium-sized apple packs 4.4 grams of fiber, a good chunk of the 21 to 25 grams recommended for women and the 30 to 38 grams recommended for men each day.

              They lower cholesterol.

              As a great source of fiber, apples are classic cholesterol busters. That’s because pectin, one type of soluble fiber, lowers LDL, or the “bad cholesterol.” A medium-sized apple packs 4.4 grams of fiber, a good chunk of the 21 to 25 grams recommended for women and the 30 to 38 grams recommended for men each day.

              And they might reduce the risk of stroke.

              White, fleshy fruits, like apples, may help lower the odds of having a stroke. One study showed that people who ate a lot of white fruits and veggies were able to reduce their stroke risk by 50 percent. Even adding as little as 25 grams of white produce in each day could lower your risk of stroke by nine percent. So munch away on those apples, pears and cauliflower.

              Apples are food for thought.

              Apples may increase your brainpower. Although the rumor that an apple has as much caffeine as a cup of coffee is definitely a myth, they do contain natural sugars that can also give you a boost. So go ahead and try subbing out that second cup of coffee for an apple this afternoon.

              More: Health, Nutrition, Cooking

	          <span class="icon icon--small icon-magnifying-glass"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="175.5 -92.5 500 500" enable-background="new 175.5 -92.5 500 500">

</svg>
</span>
	        </a> <!-- /.search-toggler -->
	      </span> <!-- /.h-hide -->
	    </div> <!-- /.lc -->

				<article class="article article-standard " itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">

						<header class="article-header  cf">
							<div class="kicker dib"><a itemprop="articleSection" href="#">Life</a>  <span class="divider">/</span> <a itemprop="articleSection" href="#">Organizing</a>  </div>
 
							<h1 class="lead-headline" itemprop="headline">Amazing Living Room Makeovers</h1>
								<h2 class="lead-subtitle" itemprop="alternativeHeadline">Discover the inspiring transformation of this stylish living room</h2>
								<div class="article-meta">
									<div class="byline" itemprop="author">By <span>Suzanne Sugarbaker</span></div>
									<time class="date" datetime="2013-04-06T12:32+00:00" itemprop="datePublished" pubdate>April 22, 2015</time>
								</div> <!-- /.article-details -->
							<div class="article-tools">

								        <span class="no-bg icon rounded icon-twitter icon--medium"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="146 290 500 500" enable-background="new 146 290 500 500">
  <title>Twitter</title>
  <path fill="#fff" d="M389.9 458.5l.9 15-15.2-1.8c-55.4-7.1-103.8-31.1-145-71.3l-20.1-20-5.2 14.7c-11 32.9-4 67.7 18.9 91 12.1 12.9 9.4 14.8-11.6 7.1-7.3-2.4-13.7-4.3-14.3-3.4-2.1 2.2 5.2 30.1 11 41.2 7.9 15.4 24.1 30.4 41.8 39.4l14.9 7-17.7.3c-17.1 0-17.7.3-15.8 6.8 6.1 20 30.2 41.2 57 50.4l18.9 6.4-16.5 9.8c-24.4 14.1-53 22.1-81.6 22.7-13.7.3-25 1.5-25 2.5 0 3.1 37.2 20.3 58.8 27.1 64.9 20 141.9 11.4 199.8-22.8 41.1-24.3 82.2-72.6 101.4-119.3 10.3-24.9 20.7-70.4 20.7-92.2 0-14.1.9-16 18-32.9 10.1-9.8 19.5-20.6 21.3-23.7 3-5.8 2.7-5.8-12.8-.6-25.9 9.2-29.6 8-16.8-5.8 9.5-9.9 20.7-27.7 20.7-32.9 0-.9-4.6.6-9.7 3.4-5.5 3.1-17.7 7.7-26.8 10.5l-16.5 5.2-14.9-10.2c-8.2-5.5-19.8-11.7-25.9-13.5-15.5-4.3-39.3-3.7-53.3 1.2-38.1 14-62.1 49.6-59.4 88.7z"/>

  <foreignObject>
    <img src="../../images/svg/output/png/twitter.png" alt="Twitter" class="no-svg-png">

</span>
								      </a> <!-- /.ss-link -->
								    </li> <!-- /.ss-item -->
								  </ul> <!-- /.ss-list -->
								</div> <!-- /.social-share -->

							</div> <!-- /.article-tools -->
						</header> <!-- /.article-header -->


					<section class="section article-body text" itemprop="articleBody">

</div>

          </div> <!-- /.has-social -->
      </div> <!-- /.img-inner -->

          <span class="credit">Left photo by Suzanne Sugarbaker, Right photo by Suzanne Sugarbaker</span>

    </div> <!-- /.img-wrap -->
							  </figure> <!-- /.figure -->

							<p>As it turns out, an apple a day really may keep the doctor away. From fighting obesity to strengthening your mind, this juicy, seasonal fruit comes with some serious health perks.</p>

							<h2>Apples may keep obesity at bay.</h2>
							<p>A new study from Washington State University found that some of the compounds in Granny Smiths, in particular, could help prevent certain disorders that lead to obesity. The sour fruit helps good bacteria in the colon grow and eventually spread to the stomach. And a healthy metabolism relies on the right amount of bacteria, which can affect inflammation levels and help us feel full and satisfied.  While the nondigestible compounds responsible for these benefits can be found in other types of apples, Granny Smiths contain the most.</p>

							<p>You may want to skip peeling your apples if you’re after the full slimming effects. Researchers at the University of Iowa linked ursolic acid, found in the peel, with a lower rate of obesity in mice. That’s because the compound seems to increase brown fat, the “good fat” that regulates your body temperature and appears to feed on regular body fat.</p>

							<table border="1" bordercolor="#ffffff" width="100%"><tbody><tr><td align="center" valign="center"><a href="http://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/browse-all-recipes/buttermilk-biscuits"><img align="center" alt="Buttermilk Biscuits" src="http://cdn-image.realsimple.com/sites/default/files/styles/rs_main_image/public/1431618647/buttermilk-biscuits.jpg" width="250" data-loaded="true"></a></td>
							      <td align="center" valign="center"><a href="http://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/browse-all-recipes/strawberry-buttermilk-smoothie"><img alt="Strawberry Buttermilk Smoothie" src="http://cdn-image.realsimple.com/sites/default/files/styles/rs_main_image/public/1431618647/buttermilk-smoothie.jpg" width="250" data-loaded="true"></a></td>
							      <td align="center" valign="center"><a href="http://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/browse-all-recipes/buttermilk-banana-honey-ice-pops"><img alt="Buttermilk, Banana, and Honey Ice Pops" src="http://cdn-image.realsimple.com/sites/default/files/styles/rs_main_image/public/1431618647/buttermilk-pops.jpg" width="250" data-loaded="true"></a></td>
							    </tr><tr><td align="center" valign="top">
							      <h4 align="center"><a href="http://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/browse-all-recipes/buttermilk-biscuits">Buttermilk Biscuits</a></h4>
							      </td>
							      <td align="center" valign="top">
							      <h4 align="center"><a href="http://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/browse-all-recipes/strawberry-buttermilk-smoothie">Strawberry Buttermilk<br>
							      Smoothie</a></h4>
							      </td>
							      <td align="center" valign="top">
							      <h4 align="center"><a href="http://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/browse-all-recipes/buttermilk-banana-honey-ice-pops">Buttermilk, Banana, and<br>
							      Honey Ice Pops</a></h4>
							      </td>
							    </tr><tr><td align="center" valign="center"><a href="http://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/browse-all-recipes/buttermilk-fried-chicken"><img alt="Buttermilk Fried Chicken" src="http://cdn-image.realsimple.com/sites/default/files/styles/rs_main_image/public/1431618647/buttermilk-chicken.jpg" width="250" data-loaded="true"></a></td>
							      <td align="center" valign="center"><a href="http://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/browse-all-recipes/garlicky-buttermilk-dressing"><img alt="Garlicky Buttermilk Dressing" src="http://cdn-image.realsimple.com/sites/default/files/styles/rs_main_image/public/1431618647/buttermilk-dressing.jpg" width="250" data-loaded="true"></a></td>
							      <td align="center" valign="center"><a href="http://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/browse-all-recipes/buttermilk-mashed-yukon-gold-potatoes"><img alt="Buttermilk Mashed Potatoes" src="http://cdn-image.realsimple.com/sites/default/files/styles/rs_main_image/public/1431618647/buttermilk-potatoes.jpg" width="250" data-loaded="true"></a></td>
							    </tr><tr><td align="center" valign="top">
							      <h4 align="center"><a href="http://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/browse-all-recipes/buttermilk-fried-chicken">Buttermilk Fried<br>
							      Chicken</a></h4>
							      </td>
							      <td align="center" valign="top">
							      <h4 align="center"><a href="http://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/browse-all-recipes/garlicky-buttermilk-dressing">Garlicky Buttermilk<br>
							      Dressing</a></h4>
							      </td>
							      <td align="center" valign="top">
							      <h4 align="center"><a href="http://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/browse-all-recipes/buttermilk-mashed-yukon-gold-potatoes">Buttermilk Mashed<br>
							      Potatoes</a></h4>
							      </td>
							    </tr></tbody></table>

							<h2>Apples could fight cancer.</h2>
							<p>An apple provides roughly 10 percent of the vitamin C and fiber we need each day. Vitamin C is great for boosting our immune system and has been linked with a lower risk of cancer in the esophagus. And dietary fiber is thought to reduce the risk of colorectal cancer, possibly because it helps with weight control. The peels of apples also contain quercetin, a flavonoid that shows anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties, which can help prevent cancer.</p>

							<h2>They lower cholesterol.</h2>
							<p>As a great source of fiber, apples are classic cholesterol busters. That’s because pectin, one type of soluble fiber, lowers LDL, or the “bad cholesterol.” A medium-sized apple packs 4.4 grams of fiber, a good chunk of the 21 to 25 grams recommended for women and the 30 to 38 grams recommended for men each day.</p>

							<h3>They lower cholesterol.</h3>
							<p>As a great source of fiber, apples are classic cholesterol busters. That’s because pectin, one type of soluble fiber, lowers LDL, or the “bad cholesterol.” A medium-sized apple packs 4.4 grams of fiber, a good chunk of the 21 to 25 grams recommended for women and the 30 to 38 grams recommended for men each day.</p>

							<h4>They lower cholesterol.</h4>
							<p>As a great source of fiber, apples are classic cholesterol busters. That’s because pectin, one type of soluble fiber, lowers LDL, or the “bad cholesterol.” A medium-sized apple packs 4.4 grams of fiber, a good chunk of the 21 to 25 grams recommended for women and the 30 to 38 grams recommended for men each day.</p>

							<h2>And they might reduce the risk of stroke.</h2>
							<p>White, fleshy fruits, like apples, may help lower the odds of having a stroke. One study showed that people who ate a lot of white fruits and veggies were able to reduce their stroke risk by 50 percent. Even adding as little as 25 grams of white produce in each day could lower your risk of stroke by nine percent. So munch away on those apples, pears and cauliflower.</p>

							<h2>Apples are food for thought.</h2>
							<p>Apples may increase your brainpower. Although the rumor that an apple has as much caffeine as a cup of coffee is definitely a myth, they do contain natural sugars that can also give you a boost. So go ahead and try subbing out that second cup of coffee for an apple this afternoon.</p>
					</section> <!-- /.article-body -->


				</article> <!-- /.article-standard -->
